Graphical abstract The influence of water on catalytic reactions and catalysts is an unavoidable point of concern in biomass valorization. In this study, we develop a fluorine-modified magnesium oxide catalyst (MgO-F) and explored the role of fluorine in the dehydrogenation of propylene glycol to hydroxyacetone in the presence of water. MgO-F is a mixed phase of magnesium oxide, magnesium fluoride, and oxyfluoride structure, resulting in changes to its electronic properties and consequently to its acidity and alkalinity. Detailed kinetics suggested that fluorine accelerates the dehydrogenation reaction rate while increasing the selectivity to allyl alcohol and propanol in absence of water. Increasing water pressure lowers the apparent barriers but hardly alters the reaction order of propylene glycol on MgO-F catalyst. In contrast, the MgO catalyst exhibits lower reaction orders and increased activation barriers under similar conditions. Further kinetic isotope effect (KIE) studies showed that the water actively participates in the reaction on MgO catalyst, whereas on the MgO-F catalyst negligible effects were observed. This weaker interaction with water led to improved stability and reduced kinetic sensitivity towards water. These results demonstrate the ability of fluorine to tailor the interaction of water molecules with metal oxide surfaces, which ultimately modifies the activity, selectivity, and stability of the catalyst. Keywords Biomass valorization Fluorine-modified Magnesium oxide Dehydrogenation Influence of water Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biomass resources are pivotal for the production of renewable materials and chemicals. Compared to traditional fossil-based chemicals, biomass has a higher water and oxygen content that can induce severe catalyst deactivation via (i) strong competitive adsorption, (ii) hydrolysis, (iii) corrosion, and/or (iv) phase transition [1,2]. This greatly complicates the utilization biomass resources when using conventional catalysts [3–5]. Next to these issues the increased reactivity of oxygen-containing functionalities in biomass leads to undesirable oligomerization reactions that lower feedstock mass utilization while potentially deactivating the catalyst via carbon deposition [6–9]. Water, recognized as a green solvent, not only upholds environmental friendliness, but it can also curtail energy costs for separation and purification [10,11]. Moreover, water assumes multifaceted roles as a solvent and catalyst in various systems [12–14]. At the interface between water and solids, H· and OH· resulting from water dissociation can exchange electrons with the substrate, leading to the formation of H+ and OH– ions. On the surface of metal oxides, water has the capacity to adsorb onto metal cations and oxygen anions, dissociating into two hydroxyl groups: one originating from water and the other from dissociated hydrogen and the oxygen on the surface. The hydrogen bonds formed between hydroxyl groups and reactive molecules as well as the hydroxyl groups themselves will induce changes in the electronic structure of the catalyst surface. Consequently, these hydroxyl groups significantly influence the wetting characteristics, thermal stability, catalytic activity, and other properties of metal oxides [15–18]. While the Grotthuss proton transfer mechanism in homogeneous catalysis is fairly well understood [19], the role of water in heterogeneous catalytic reactions is rather complex [10]. Studies indicate that water molecules participate in proton transfer processes, forming H3O+-like transition states, reducing activation energy barriers, and subsequently enhancing reaction rates [20]. Similarly, investigations on Ru/TiO2 catalyzed hydrogenation reveal that the reaction rate was enhanced in presence of water, which was participating in the C=O hydrogenation of levulinic acid [21]. These so-called solvation effects can induce changes in the observed reaction rates and apparent barriers depending on the transition state of the reaction [12,22], the pH of the media [23–25], hydrophobicity of the pores [26,27], the presence of surface modifiers [28–32], and concentration of water [33]. On one hand, one can find effects induced by the direct participation of water molecules in the kinetically relevant step by accelerating proton-electron transfer reactions. These effects often result in the reduction of the apparent barriers [34]. On the other hand, the presence of water pockets inside confined pores can be enthalpically unfavorable, particularly when non-polar species are involved in the reaction such as those involved in the epoxidation of alkenes, which increases the apparent barrier for activation. This effect is accompanied by a substantial entropic gain as the distorted water generated upon reaching the transition state leads to a large rate enhancement [35]. In this context, understanding the exact impact of the water molecules on the reaction is essential to develop catalysts with tailored stability and activity. Heterogeneous catalysts used in biomass conversion reactions are often supported on porous materials like Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, and various carbon supports. These materials are inherently hydrophilic due to surface functional groups [36]. In these systems, the increase of H+ or OH– ions concentration will activate the hydrolysis of the M−O−M bonds in the support leading to losses in surface area, and catalyst lixiviation. The protons in solution (Haq +) hydrates to form hydronium ions (H3Oaq +) in aqueous solutions, exhibiting stronger adsorption than other ions. Consequently, under hydrothermal conditions, active sites exposed to the reaction medium may be compromised, impacting catalyst efficiency [37–39]. This loss could lead to environmental pollution, economic losses, and necessitate additional purification steps, complicating the process [37,40]. For instance, high-temperature aqueous phase conditions can destabilize the pore structure of mesoporous oxide materials, leading to significant surface area reduction [36,37,41,42]. Therefore, considering the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst support at elevated temperatures is pivotal for biomass conversion. The stability of the catalyst in the presence of water can be improved by reducing the density of structural defects on the metal oxide, allowing the system to operate for long reaction time at high temperature and pressure [43,44]. Alternatively, one could use organosilanes to hydrophobize the surface, which ultimately heals the structural defects preventing the degradation via hydrolysis [45]. Also, the utilization of materials with inherently hydrophobic surfaces can help to improve the stability in the presence of water [46]. Similar solutions have been explored using fluorine as capping agent during hydrothermal synthesis [47], which leads to faceted crystals bearing surface fluorine. While these materials show substantial improvement on their stability in the presence of water, the underlying impact of these functionalities on the reaction kinetics is largely unknown. In the present study, we developed a fluorine-modified magnesium oxide catalyst and explored the role of fluorine groups on the activity and stability during reaction in the presence of water. To probe these effects, we employed the dehydrogenation of propylene glycol (PG) to hydroxyacetone (HA), which is a reaction relevant in the valorization of biomass to chemicals. Hydroxyacetone plays an important role in organic synthesis and finds application in food, textile, cosmetic industries as well as in the production of polymers [48,49]. Glycerol direct dehydration is a common process for producing HA [50]. Meanwhile, propylene glycol is a by-product from the conversion of sugar into ethylene glycol [51,52]. Consequently, research on the high-value conversion of propylene glycol has attracted more and more attention. Pramod et al. reported two different pathways for the conversion of propylene glycol into lactic acid and acrylic acid. In the first one, the authors employed a direct oxidation process of the primary alcohol to the acid. The second one was based on a sequential dehydration of propylene glycol to allyl alcohol followed by oxidation into acrylic acid [53]. The authors found that the latter pathway is more favorable [54]. During the investigation of catalyst performance, the acidity and alkalinity of the catalyst were adjusted to enhance the selectivity to allyl alcohol. Ultimately, it was observed that the active chemical properties of the reaction raw materials and intermediate products contributed to the complexity of the reaction products. To elucidate the correlation between the physical and chemical properties of catalysts and their activity, propylene glycol to hydroxyacetone was chosen as the model, as hydroxyacetone can be directly generated from the dehydrogenation of propylene glycol. To interrogate the catalyst and the reaction mechanism we combined reaction kinetics, kinetic isotope effect investigations, catalyst characterization, and transition state treatments for the reaction. The results suggest that fluorine effectively weakened the water binding, which in turn leads to higher apparent barriers. This enthalpic penalty is accompanied by an entropic enhancement that induces a large catalytic activity. Next to these kinetic effects, the large differences in stability of the catalysts suggests that fluorine can improve the water-tolerance of the catalyst. These results underscore the importance of water surface interactions on the overall kinetics and structural stability of the catalyst, which is essential during biomass conversion. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The materials used in the experiment were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich, including magnesium ethoxide (Mg(OC2H5)2, 98 %), ammonium hydrogen difluoride (NH4∙HF2, AHDF, 99.999 %), deuterium oxide (D2O, 99.95 %), propylene glycol (CH3CH(OH)CH2OH, PG, >99.5 %), hydroxyacetone (CH3C(O)CH2OH, HA, >99.5 %), and magnesium hydroxide (Mg(OH)2, 95 %). For liquid aliquot sampling during the reaction to determine reaction rates, a syringe filter (PTFE 0.2 μm, Whatman) and sampling syringe (BD Plastipak) were utilized. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The materials are prepared through a direct hydrothermal treatment of the magnesium precursors. Initially, 2.86 g of magnesium ethoxide is dissolved in 20 mL of deionized water within Teflon beakers. Subsequently, 0.55 g of AHDF is introduced to the solution. The resulting mixture is then transferred to a Teflon container located inside a 150 mL stainless steel autoclave, where it undergoes hydrothermal treatment at 373 K for a duration of 10 h. Following this treatment, a cloudy liquid is obtained, and the resulting precipitate is subjected to centrifugation. The precipitate is then repeatedly washed with ethanol and subsequently dried overnight at 353 K within a vacuum oven. The final mixture is subjected to calcination at a temperature of 623 K in a static air environment for 2 h, and the resulting product is referred to as MgO-F. If the AHDF was not involved in the above process, the obtained sample was designated as MgO. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystallized phases of the catalyst were analyzed using X-ray diffraction (XRD) on an Empyrean PANalytical X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) at room temperature. The 2θ range was set from 5° to 90° with a step size of 0.02°. Thermogravimetric (TG) of different samples were carried out and the ionic current (IC) curves of gases simultaneously evolved from the sample (TG-DTG-MS) were obtained using a METTLER TOLEDO TGA/DSC 3 + thermoanalyser equipped with a quadrupole mass spectrometer PFEIFFER GSD350 in air at a ramping rate of 10 K /min from 303 to 1023 K. The ionization energy was 70 eV and the detection mode was multi-ion detection. The sample with about 10 mg was used for each measurement. The mass fragments of the evolved gases including water (m/z = 18), PG (m/z = 76), and HA (m/z = 75) were collected. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using a monochromatized Al Ka source at a power of 15 kV and 3 mA (45 W). The C 1s (C−C) peak from the carbon-based contaminant with a literature value of 284.8 eV was used as a reference to calibrate the XPS spectra and eliminate charging effects. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area analysis was conducted by using a Micromeritics Model ASAP 2400 instrument. For each analysis, 0.2–0.3 g of sample was degassed at 573 K for 10 h before measurement. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis results were obtained by using a Tecnai F30 field emission TEM. The Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) was conducted by using a JEOL, LA6010 with a resolution of 4 nm @ 20 kV. The energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS) mapping was conducted using an FEI Talos F200X, and the spectrum model is Super X with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The elemental concentration of Mg and F in the samples was determined using an μ-X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometer (ELEMENTAR Vario ELIII) with an uncertainty of 3 %. The temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) measurements were performed on an AutoChem II 2920 instrument (Micromeritics, USA) for comparing the acidity of various samples. Before the NH3-TPD studies, a sample of 100 mg was first pretreated in pure He at 623 K for 60 min, then cooled to 393 K and saturated at this temperature with anhydrous ammonia gas (10 % in He) for 30 min. Weakly adsorbed NH3 was eliminated by treatment under He at the same temperature for 60 min. The NH3-TPD profile was recorded with a thermal conductivity detector with a heating rate of 10 K min−1 from 393 to 973 K in a He flow. The temperature-programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD) measurement was also performed on the AutoChem II 2920 for comparing the basicity of various samples. Prior to CO2-TPD studies, a sample of 100 mg was first pretreated in pure He at 623 K for 60 min, then cooled to 343 K and saturated at this temperature with anhydrous CO2 (10 % in He) for 30 min. Weakly adsorbed CO2 was eliminated by treatment under He at the same temperature for 120 min. The CO2-TPD profile was recorded with a thermal conductivity detector with a heating rate of 10 K min−1 from 343 to 773 K in a He flow. The CO2-TPD of MgO and MgO-F after steam treatment consisted in the following steps. First, the sample is placed in a quartz furnace tube and heated from room temperature to 575 K under N2. Then, the gas was switched to N2 water vapor saturated at room temperature (0.0313 atm) for 30 min after reaching steady state. After this treatment, the N2 containing water vapor switched to N2 and the sample was quenched to room temperature under pure N2. After that, the sample was carefully transfer to the CO2-TPD without exposure to the ambient. The FTIR-photoacoustic spectroscopy of chemisorbed pyridine (Py-IR) was used to determine the nature of the acid sites (Lewis and Brønsted acid sites) by a PerkinElmer FT-IR Frontier spectrometer and a self-supported wafer of sample. The sample was pretreated at 623 K for 1 h under vacuum prior to pyridine adsorption. Pyridine was adsorbed at room temperature from an argon flow for 0.5 h. Then, the samples were heated to 473 K and evacuated to remove physisorbed and weakly chemisorbed pyridine. 2.4 Catalytic tests The catalytic dehydrogenation of propylene glycol (PG) to hydroxyacetone (HA) was conducted in a fixed-bed stainless steel reactor with an inner diameter of 0.8 cm and 60 cm in length. Approximately 0.05 g of catalyst was centrally placed in the reactor using quartz wool. The powdered catalysts were sieved in the 80–100 μm range for the catalytic tests. The reactor was heated in three stages, each with two thermocouples. One of them, which controlled the temperature of the oven, was placed in the internal wall of the oven. The other one, fixed on the outer wall of the reactor, was used to measure the real temperature achieved in the different stage, providing a reference value that temperature regulation of first thermocouple. A feed containing a PG/H2O mixture at the stoichiometric ratio of the reaction was introduced into the system via an ISCO 500D syringe pump, carried with N2 using calibrated mass flow controllers (Brooks) after passing through the preheater section of the setup. The system remained open at the outlet, guaranteeing an atmospheric pressure in the system. Liquid product samples could be extracted from a gas/liquid separator, each sample to be tested was balanced for two hours and then analyzed using high-pressure liquid chromatography (Shimadzu HPLC-10A) equipped with an autosampler. All kinetics were measured at low conversion levels (<10 %), avoiding internal and external mass transfer limitations, and maintaining a distance from catalyst deactivation and thermodynamic limitations. The propylene glycol conversion, hydroxyacetone selectivity and activity were calculated with Eqs. (1)–(3). (1) Propylene glycol conversion t 1 = ( [ PG ] t 0 - - [ PG ] t 1 ) / [ PG ] t 0 × 1 00 % (2) Hydroxyacetone selectivity t 2 = [ HA ] t 1 / ( [ PG ] t 0 - - [ PG ] t 1 ) × 1 00 % (3) Activity = F × Conv . / ( w cat . × S cat . ) where [PG] t0– is the initial concentration of propylene glycol, [PG] t1 is the concentration of propylene glycol at t1, [HA] t1 is the concentration of hydroxyacetone at t1. F is the mole flow of the propylene glycol (mmol/min), Conv. is the conversion of propylene glycol (%), wcat. is the weight of catalyst (g), the Scat. is the specific surface area of the catalyst, m2/g. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The incorporation of fluorine significantly affects the final structural configuration of the samples (Fig. 1 a). The XRD analysis of MgO revealed characteristic peaks at 36.9°, 42.8°, 62.1°, and 78.4°, corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), and (222) planes of MgO, respectively, confirming the formation of the MgO phase (PDF card 74—1225) [55,56]. Conversely, MgO-F exhibited a less distinct pattern, suggesting a more amorphous sample. While no evident peaks corresponding to MgO or MgF2 were observed, peaks at 18.6°, 38°, and 50.9° were attributed to Mg(OH)2 (PDF card 76–0667) [57]. The XRD results of the MgO-F precursor (Fig. S1) suggests that catalyst formation began through the progressive crystallization of Mg(OH)2 at elevated temperatures. Gaussian fitting of the MgO-F sample in the 33-49° range displayed distinct peaks at 38°, 40.4°, 42.8°, and 43.8° (Fig. 1b), corresponding to characteristic diffraction peaks of the Mg(OH)2 phase, MgF2 phase (PDF card 06–0290) [58], and MgO phase, respectively. This indicates the formation of a mixed phase during the heat treatment of the MgO-F precursor. Upon further increase of the calcination temperature (Fig. S1), the peaks attributed to Mg(OH)2 gradually diminished and were replaced by emerging peaks attributed to MgF2. Concurrently, peaks characteristic of MgO also emerged. At 773 K, only the peaks related to MgO and MgF2 were observable in the XRD pattern. The qualitative analysis of the EDX-Mapping results (Fig. 1c) suggests uniform distribution of fluorine across both the catalyst surface and bulk. It is noteworthy to mention that the specific surface area of the fluorine modified MgO catalyst significantly increased (Table S1), maintaining this enhancement regardless of the rise in treatment temperature. This underscores that the preparation method adopted in this study modifies the crystal structure favoring the formation of Mg-O-F upon addition of fluorine. The structural analysis of both samples was further investigated using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) coupled to on-line mass spectroscopy, with commercial Mg(OH)2 utilized as a reference. Commercial Mg(OH)2 exhibited no signal for desorbing physically bonded water molecules at low temperatures (Fig. S3). At high temperatures, however, a substantial weight loss of approximately 27.7 wt% was observed between room temperature and 674 K. This value further increased to 31.2 wt% when temperatures up to 773 K were reached. These observations closely align with the theoretical value for the conversion of anhydrous Mg(OH)2 to MgO (c.a. 30.86 %) as reported in previous work [55,59]. The synthesized MgO and MgO-F samples displayed two prominent weight loss regions. The initial region below 473 K primarily indicated water loss from the samples, supported by the strong peak in the ion current (IC) curve for the mass number m/z 18. The weight loss associated with this region was quite similar for both samples, measured at 15.3 wt% for MgO-F and 15.9 wt% for MgO. A more significant discrepancy was observed in the second weight loss region. MgO exhibited a convergence to final equilibrium around 677 K, consistent with the commercial Mg(OH)2 results (Fig. 2 b) and the IC curve also detected the m/z 18. The weight loss rate amounted to about 39.1 %, surpassing the theoretical value, potentially due to the liberation of physically adsorbed water molecules associated with the sample [55]. In contrast, MgO-F demonstrated different thermal decomposition behavior (Fig. 2a). The final temperature point of weight loss increased to 725 K, with a weight loss rate of around 35 %, lower than that of MgO. Here, the m/z 18 was the only signal in the IC curve. To interpret these results, one could combine the observed XRD and SEM-EDS data with the TGA-MS. The XRD results suggested that the final calcined structure of MgO-F constituted a mixed phase of MgF2 and MgO, with MgF2 being the predominant phase (Fig. S1). Here, one must note that stoichiometric reactions between Mg(OH)2 and HF, as outlined in the literature [55,60], can lead to the formation of pure MgF2 when the Mg/F ratio is 1/2 (Eq. (4)). Further increasing the Mg ratio to 2/3 can result in a mixed phase of MgF2 and Mg(OH)F (Eq. (5)). The subsequent decomposition of Mg(OH)F can result in the formation of MgO and MgF2 within this temperature range (Eq. (6)). In this line, if one considers that the molar ratio of Mg/F utilized in this experiment was 1.3/1, corresponding to an excess of magnesium salt, then it is possible that the resulting material is in fact a Mg−O−F nanocomposite, comprised of MgF2 and MgO within the MgO-F sample. XPS and XRF gave further element concentrations (Table 1 ), which the F was constant on the surface and in the bulk. Such structure would be consistent with observed XRD and EDX-mapping outcomes (Fig. 1). (4) Mg(OH)2 + 2HF → MgF2 + 2H2O (5) 2 Mg(OH)2 + 3HF → MgF2 + Mg(OH)F + 3H2O (6) 2[Mg(OH)F] → MgF2 + MgO + H2O XPS analysis further delved into the electronic states of Mg and O in both the MgO sample with and without fluorine. Due to the absence of reliable C 1s peaks, the Mg 2p peaks at 50 eV were used for the correction of the spectra. The Mg 2p region in both samples displayed two Gaussian peaks at 50.4 and 49.6 eV (Figs. 3 a and d), corresponding to MgO and Mg(OH)2, respectively [61]. The relative concentration of these two species remained consistent between the two samples. The O 1s region exhibited significant differences between MgO-F and MgO (Figs. 3b and e). The peaks in this region could also be deconvoluted into two peaks, representing O2– and OH– at approximately 529 and 530 eV, respectively [61]. However, the primary species in MgO-F were OH–, while in MgO, it was O2–, aligning well with the XRD results (Fig. 1a). Additionally, the binding energy of O2– in MgO-F was lower than that in MgO, while the binding energy of OH– in MgO-F was higher than that in MgO, indicating the strong electronegativity of F impacted on the MgO-F is complex [62], as discussed below. The XPS analysis confirms the presence of fluorine on the surface of the MgO-F catalyst (Fig. 3c), consistent with the SEM-mapping results (Fig. S4). The F 1s peak at 686 eV originates from MgF2 [63,64], while the peak at a binding energy of 685.4 eV is attributed to F bound to unsaturated Mg [62]. Notably, the dominant species observed in the F 1s are those corresponding to unsaturated fluorine. The observations regarding the calcination temperature and transformations of the MgO-F precursor from amorphous Mg(OH)2 into MgO and MgF2 with increasing temperature are intriguing. It has been reported that as the degree of crystallization increases, the coordination of fluorine increases until reaching saturation [65–67]. This indicates a structural evolution within the material, potentially influencing its properties and chemical behavior. Additionally, the thermogravimetric analysis (Fig. 2a) and the equations deduced (Eqs. (4)–(6)) suggest that the intermediate Mg(OH)F structure dominates in the sample used for XPS analysis, leading to the prevalence of unsaturated F species. Moreover, the XPS analysis of Mg 1s (Fig. 3f) revealed two fitted peaks corresponding to MgF2 and unsaturated magnesium, [62] with the latter being predominant, which aligns with the findings in the F 1s results. Comparing these Mg 1s analysis results to those of the MgO sample (Fig. S5), it is observed that the presence of the Mg(OH)F structure contributes to a higher Mg 1s binding energy on the MgO-F catalyst [68]. This structural aspect may introduce a certain degree of Lewis acidity to the catalyst surface [55,65]. Meanwhile, the binding energy associated with OH– in MgO-F, as observed in the O 1s region, also shifted to a higher energy (Figs. 3b and e), indicating that the oxygen atom of MgO-F possesses lower electron density compared to that of MgO. This reduction could lead to a strong polarization of the O–H bond, resulting in hydrogen ionization [69,70]. Consequently, this process may derive into Brønsted-acid sites in MgO-F. While it is tempting to use XPS data to infer the changes in strength of acid and basic sites one must remember that these measurements are conducted in conditions that differ substantially from those of the reaction. For this reason, it is important to compare these results with a surface probe technique such as temperature programmed desorption of carbon dioxide and ammonia as well as pyridine chemisorption. In this line, more direct evidence of the catalyst acidity was compiled using IR absorption of pyridine (Fig. S6c and Table 1). In addition to the absorption bands at approximately 1448 and 1610 cm−1, indicative of Lewis acid sites [70,71], an adsorption band around 1490 cm−1 was also observed in the MgO-F sample, which has been attributed to both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites [72]. 3.2 Dehydrogenation of propylene glycol to hydroxyacetone The analysis of internal and external mass transfer limitations, elaborated in the Supporting Information (Section S2), demonstrated negligible impact of mass transport limitations under the reaction conditions herein explored. In Fig. 4 a, the both conversion were comparable between the MgO-F and MgO catalysts when the reaction was carried out at different temperatures in the absence of water. Here, slightly faster rates were observed on the fluorinated catalyst. The activity consistently increased with rising temperature. A notable difference was observed in the temperature sensitivity of the two catalysts. In the case of MgO a nearly linear change in the rate was observed as a function of temperature, while for MgO-F a more pronounced increased was observed. Fig. 4b illustrates the product selectivity of both catalysts at similar conversion rates. Hydroxyacetone (HA) emerged as the primary product in both cases, with a higher yield on the MgO catalyst. Additionally, trace amounts of allyl alcohol (AA) and other unidentified components were also detected on the MgO catalyst. In contrast, the product composition on the MgO-F catalyst was notably more complex. The relative contents of the secondary product, 1-propanol (POL), and the dehydrated product, AA, were higher compared to the MgO catalyst. Furthermore, the detection of acetone (AC) and propanal (PAL) contributed to the product mix, highlighting a more diversified product profile for MgO-F compared to MgO. 3.3 Apparent reaction orders and apparent activation Energies of propylene glycol to hydroxyacetone Reaction kinetics were carried out using the propylene glycol to hydroxyacetone reaction to interrogate the underlying mechanism operating on the MgO-F and MgO catalysts. The apparent reaction order of PG was 0.36 ± 0.09 for MgO, while MgO-F exhibited first-order kinetics for the same reactant (Fig. 5 a). By varying the temperature, we determined the apparent barriers of the reaction for both catalysts (see Fig. S8 and Table S3). The activation energy (Ea) for PG on MgO-F was 60.3 ± 3.2 kJ/mol, while on the MgO catalyst a lower barrier of 43.6 ± 5.2 kJ/mol was obtained (see Fig. 5b). The observed higher apparent orders on MgO-F points towards a weaker interaction between propylene glycol molecules and the catalyst surface. In that context, the higher activation energy barriers are more difficult to rationalize as one would expect lower barriers on partly covered surfaces. Nevertheless, if scaling relationships apply to this system, then it is possible that this weaker binding leads to higher true barriers [1–5]. This suggests that the reaction mechanism and surface interactions significantly differ between MgO-F and MgO catalysts during the propylene glycol conversion process. 3.4 Influence of water on propylene glycol to hydroxyacetone The examination of activity values on both catalysts in the presence of water (Fig. 6 a) revealed a positive impact on their performance. Notably, the increase in activity was more significant for MgO compared to MgO-F, with growth ratios of 1.33 times for MgO and 1.12 times for MgO-F. While the product selectivity exhibited different trends with varying water partial pressure conditions, the overall observation was that the selectivity of the primary product, HA, increases with water partial pressure. Conversely, the selectivity of the by-product, POL, decreased (Fig. S9). Subsequently, the apparent reaction orders of PG were measured on both catalysts in the presence of water. Here, we observed stark differences. In the case of the mother MgO catalyst the addition of water resulted in higher reaction orders with values of 0.66 ± 0.07, while for the MgO-F the values remained unchanged (Fig. 6b). The analysis of the apparent activation barriers on MgO suggests that increased water partial pressure led to higher barriers (Table 2 ). This trend goes hand in hand with a slightly negative reaction order of water on this catalyst (−0.15 ± 0.01) (Fig. S12). In sharp contrast, on the MgO-F catalyst, the addition of water lowered the apparent barriers, and the reaction order of water was nearly zero (0.057 ± 0.01) (Fig. S12). 4 Discussion 4.1 Bridging catalyst chemistry and performance It is clear that the addition of fluorine induces large changes in the activity and selectivity of MgO. First, we noticed that in the absence of water co-feeding MgO displayed a lower reaction order for PG and apparent activation barrier than its fluorinated counterpart. Here, it is important to consider that the product distribution is essentially dominated by the formation of hydroxyacetone on both catalysts. For this reason, we have purposely focused on the rates of hydroxyacetone formation per surface area. In addition, we have subtracted the formation of hydroxyacetone via Meerwein–Ponndorf–Verley reduction of allyl alcohol with propylene glycol. In this line, if the rate determining step and transition state complex for these two catalysts is the same, then the changes in the binding energy of the kinetically controlling species will dictate the observed apparent barriers and reaction orders. Here, the near zero orders for PG measured on the MgO would suggest that on this catalyst the surface must be saturated by this specie. In this scenario, the larger coverage of PG could explain the lower reaction rates obtained, as competitive adsorption between PG and the reaction products would inhibit the reaction. Upon addition of fluorine the weak and strong basic sites, initially present in the MgO catalyst, disappear and the density of medium basic sites drastically increases (Fig. S6a). This could have weakened the PG-surface binding on the basic sites and thus decrease the surface coverage. This would explain the higher apparent orders of reaction and activation barriers obtained in the MgO-F [73–75]. On these catalysts there are no metallic centers that can activate the homolytic dissociation of O–H nor C–H bonds. Instead, the alcohol is dehydrogenated by the basic sites that can accept a proton, while the metal cations on the metal oxide coordinate the hydride on the surface. The proton and the hydride recombine to form hydrogen. On basic metal oxides it is believed that the C–H bond scission is the rate determining step, via an inner-sphere electron-transfer process [76,77]. This proposition suggests that two distinct sites are required to conduct the reaction. One site with a basic character that can accept the proton from the alcohol moiety on the PG, and one with a Lewis acid character that can stabilize the hydride resulting from the cleavage of the C–H bond from the carbonyl carbon (Fig. S6c). The resulting proton and hydride would recombine to form hydrogen, which desorbs from the surface together with the newly formed ketone. The underlying question here is if the active sites required for the hydrogen formation are the same as those involved in the activation of the alcohol on these two catalysts. To address this question, we conducted experiments co-feeding hydrogen during propylene glycol dehydrogenation (Fig. S12b). The results indicated the reaction order of hydrogen less than 0, −0.73 ± 0.15 and −0.31 ± 0.01 for MgO-F and MgO, respectively. This undoubtably indicates competitive adsorption between hydrogen and PG on these catalysts. Furthermore, the involvement of hydrogen contributes to the reduction of catalyst reactivity (Fig. S12a), emphasizing the competitive adsorption. Therefore, in this reaction propylene glycol dehydrogenation and hydrogen dissociation share the same active site. The more negative reaction order on MgO-F would suggest that on this surface the binding of either the hydride or the proton could be enhanced by the presence of fluorine. Since the acidity of this catalyst increases substantially it is possible that the strongly binding of the hydride on the surface is the responsible for this inhibition. Now that we have rationalized the activity trends on these catalysts, we can discuss the differences in selectivity. Here, one can note that on the MgO-F catalyst the selectivity of the second product 1-propanol and allyl alcohol increases. To convert the propylene glycol to 1-propanol one could follow two routes. In the first one, one could imagine that propylene glycol undergoes direct C-O hydrogenolysis. This process, however, requires a metal site to activate the homolytic dissociation of hydrogen and the H-insertion on the carbonyl carbon and C-O scission [78]. This cannot occur on these catalysts as there is no metallic function that could activate these reactions. In the second one, a Brønsted acid site (Fig. S6c) could catalyzed the dehydration of the secondary alkoxy group on propylene glycol to form allyl alcohol. This specie can undergo reduction via hydride transfer on Lewis acid sites via Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley (MPV) reaction in which propylene glycol and allyl alcohol react with each other to yield hydroxyacetone and 1-propanol, respectively [79–81]. In this process the allyl alcohol is a highly reactive intermediate that can readily subtract a hydrogen and proton from the propylene glycol (Fig. 7 ) [53]. The high reactivity of this specie would explain the low concentration on the product stream. Similar observations have been reported on Sc2O3 catalysts in which the Sc uncoordinated sites acted as Lewis acid sites for the MPV reaction [82]. 4.2 The role of water The impact of water on the reaction behaviors of the two catalysts, MgO and MgO-F, suggests distinct mechanisms. In terms of reaction performance, one can note that propylene glycol co-feeding with water enhanced the reaction rate of both catalysts, but the magnitude of improvement differs. That is that in the case of MgO a greater enhancement was observed compared to the fluorinated catalyst (Fig. 6a). At the same time, in the presence of water, the reaction order of propylene glycol increased significantly over MgO, almost doubling from 0.36 ± 0.09 to 0.66 ± 0.07. Conversely, over MgO-F, the reaction order of PG decreases slightly from 1.0 ± 0.02 to 0.86 ± 0.07 (Fig. 5a and Fig. 6b). Next to this, the apparent activation energy for propylene glycol dehydrogenation on MgO gradually increased with the water partial pressure, whereas the opposite trend is observed on MgO-F (Table 2). Finally, when the partial pressure of water was increased the rate of reaction of dehydrogenation decreased substantially for the MgO catalyst, while in the case of the MgO-F the activity remained unaltered (see Fig. S10). These observations indicate that adding water to this system induces different changes in the catalyst operation. Micro-analysis of the catalyst surface using XPS indicated that on the MgO catalyst the electron binding energy of the O 1s peak significantly increased due to the formation of OH– groups on spent sample (Fig. 8 b). Conversely, over MgO-F O 1s region remained unaltered after reaction (Fig. 8a). Overall, these experimental and characterization results indicate that water may participate in the reaction over MgO catalyst, while in the case of MgO-F catalyst these effects are attenuated. This would be in line with the zero order in water for the reaction rate compared to the negative orders observed on MgO. 4.3 Reaction mechanism in presence of water Understanding the complexities introduced by water addition in altering the reaction kinetics on both MgO-F and MgO catalysts is crucial. While the reaction selectivity remains unchanged upon the addition of water (Fig. S9), the reaction kinetics are notably affected, particularly on the MgO catalyst (Figs. 5 and 6). The impact of water addition on the underlying reaction mechanism is complex. However, by analyzing the obtained apparent reaction orders, one can infer the potential rate-determining steps in process. For instance, assuming the reaction involves the molecular adsorption of propylene glycol on the active site, followed by sequential dehydrogenation reactions leading to the formation of hydroxyacetone, one could develop a Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson (LHHW) mechanism that could be used to check if the apparent reactor orders are feasible or not for a given rate determining step. In this qualitative analysis one could also include water as a competing surface specie as well as a participating intermediate shuttling protons on the surface via outer sphere proton-electron transfer. A similar analysis was proposed by E. Iglesia’s group for the conversion of oxygenated species on metal oxides [83,84]. The detailed derivation and expression of the LHHW reaction mechanism to accommodate these observations have been provided in depth in the Supporting Information, Section S3. While it is true that this is a simple qualitative analysis, it provides a theoretical framework to explain the observed changes in reaction kinetics on these two catalysts. The addition of water significantly impacts the reaction behavior of PG on both catalysts. If the reaction is conducted in an anhydrous environment, the assumed rate-determining step would involve dehydrogenated propylene glycol (DPG) losing one hydrogen atom (Eq. (7)), referred as Mechanism I. Interestingly, we have observed that even in the presence of water, the reaction order range of PG remains unchanged (Table 3 ). This is possible because water can occupy active sites without active participation in the reaction. However, when water does get involved in the reaction, the assumed rate-determining step becomes the interaction between DPG and hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface that are formed by water dissociation (Eq. (8)), referred as Mechanism II. (7) D P G ∗ + ∗ ⇌ H A ∗ + H ∗ (8) D P G ∗ + O H ∗ → H A ∗ + H 2 O + ∗ To unravel these effects, we conducted additional experiments employing D2O. A notably strong kinetic isotope effect (KIE) of 1.9 ± 0.07 was observed on the MgO catalyst, indicating active participation of water in the reaction. This process typically involves an outer shell electron transfer in which the water molecules create a pathway for fast redox of this alcohol [6–8]. In contrast, the MgO-F catalyst displayed a KIE of only 1.1 ± 0.06, suggesting that the water co-fed into the system had no-direct involvement in the rate limiting step on the MgO-F catalyst (Fig. 9 ). The divergent behavior of the two catalysts under different water partial pressures further solidifies the proposition that addition of fluorine on MgO provides a weaker interaction of the surface with water molecules. The KIE effects and the changes in the apparent barriers and reaction orders would indicate that in the case of MgO water molecules are involved in the transition state. Previous microkinetic model reported by H. T. Abdulrazzaq et al. on MgO and MgO-SiO2 indicated that the dehydrogenation of alcohols on metal oxides is controlled by the C–H bond dissociation in which the alpha H- on the carbonyl group is removed by a surface oxygen (basic site), while the metal cation (Lewis acid) serves as adsorption site for the stabilization of the ethoxide [85]. Similarly, theoretical work done by W. E. Taifan et al. indicated that on MgO-based catalysts the rate determining step for the dehydrogenation of ethanol is the C–H bond dissociation, in which surface basic and Lewis acid sites cooperate for the formation of acetaldehyde and hydrogen [86]. It has been reported also that in the presence of water it is possible to accelerate the reaction rate by “shuttling protons” via surface hydroxyl groups (see Figs. 10 a, b). In this scenario, the hydroxyl surface moiety abstracts the alpha hydrogen in the carbonyl group. The strong KIE observed in the presence of heavy water would indicate that this process is affected by the D2O dissociation, which could suggest that the O-D and C–H bond dissociation steps are involved in the RDS. In contrast, for the MgO-F the weak interaction of water with its surface prevents the direct participation in the reaction (Figs. 10 c, d). While at this stage, this explanation remains speculative, the strong correlation between the changes in the reaction rates, surface chemistry, and kinetic isotope effect with water addition suggest that utilization of fluorination of metal oxides has the potential to alter the role of water during the conversion of oxygenated species. Finally, we conducted stability tests in which the two catalysts were initially evaluated at low conversion (c.a. 5–10 %) for six hours, then the residence time inside the catalyst bed was increased to push the conversion to 30 % for several hours. After this process, the space velocity was increased to reduce the conversion again to the initial values (5–10 %). Strikingly, this test revealed negligible deactivation on MgO-F compared to MgO (Fig. S13), indicating the controllable adjustment of the water binding on the magnesium oxide catalyst facilitated by the addition of fluorine. 5 Conclusions Overall, this study demonstrates the successful modification of the activity and stability of magnesium oxide catalysts for biomass conversion through fluorination in the presence of water. The MgO-F catalyst exhibited enhanced catalytic performance and increasing the selectivity to allyl alcohol and propanol in the dehydrogenation of propylene glycol to hydroxyacetone, attributed to the stronger Lewis acid sites that can activate MPV reaction. The addition of water to the system had a negative impact on the reaction performance of magnesium oxide catalysts, while introducing fluorine weakened the interaction with water molecules, leading to improved stability and reduced sensitivity against water. This work collectively demonstrate that the addition of fluorine enables the controllable adjustment of the water interaction with the magnesium oxide catalyst, contributing to the advancement of sustainable chemical synthesis. coredata.dc:description: The influence of water on catalytic reactions and catalysts is an unavoidable point of concern in biomass valorization. In this study, we develop a fluorine-modified magnesium oxide catalyst (MgO-F) and explored the role of fluorine in the dehydrogenation of propylene glycol to hydroxyacetone in the presence of water. MgO-F is a mixed phase of magnesium oxide, magnesium fluoride, and oxyfluoride structure, resulting in changes to its electronic properties and consequently to its acidity and alkalinity. Detailed kinetics suggested that fluorine accelerates the dehydrogenation reaction rate while increasing the selectivity to allyl alcohol and propanol in absence of water. Increasing water pressure lowers the apparent barriers but hardly alters the reaction order of propylene glycol on MgO-F catalyst. In contrast, the MgO catalyst exhibits lower reaction orders and increased activation barriers under similar conditions. Further kinetic isotope effect (KIE) studies showed that the water actively participates in the reaction on MgO catalyst, whereas on the MgO-F catalyst negligible effects were observed. This weaker interaction with water led to improved stability and reduced kinetic sensitivity towards water. These results demonstrate the ability of fluorine to tailor the interaction of water molecules with metal oxide surfaces, which ultimately modifies the activity, selectivity, and stability of the catalyst.
